Name: propylene production, from methanol-to-propylene conversion | petrol, low-sulfur | EN15804GD, U
Category: C:Manufacturing/20:Manufacture of chemicals and chemical products/201:Manufacture of basic chemicals, fertilizers and nitrogen compounds, plastics/2011:Manufacture of basic chemicals
Description: In this dataset, the catalytic conversion of methanol to propylene is based on the work by Rodríguez-Vallejo et al. (2020). First, the methanol feedstock, before being fed into the dimethyl ether (DME) synthesis reactor, is pumped, and heated to the expected operating conditions. Namely, the reaction takes place at 300°C and 1.65 bar, attaining a 90% methanol equilibrium conversion that resembles typical industrial yields and conditions.;Subsequently, the reactor outlet, consisting of a DME and methanol mixture, is fed into the methanol-to-propylene (MTP) reactor, filled with a ZSM-5 catalyst. In the reactor, the mixture is converted mainly to olefins, such as (1) ethylene; (2) propylene; (3) C4 olefins, (4) C5 olefins; and (v) higher hydrocarbons, ranging from C6 to C10 (such as hexene(s), heptane(s), octenes, nonene(s), and decene(s)).;The MTP reactor operates at 425°C and 1.65 bar, that ensures the high methanol/DME conversion to propylene, while the overall reaction scheme is exothermic. The released heat from the latter exothermic reactor is used in a Rankine cycle to generate electricity, which is consumed internally. Any excess of generated electricity is considered as a valuable by-product.  ;The MTP reactor outlet is then cooled to 40°C, where an aqueous and organic phase is generated, and fed into a flash unit to remove the aqueous phase. The gaseous organic phase is pressurized in a three-stage compression train, with intermediate cooling, at 28.2 bar. The compressed stream is fed into a distillation column where a mixture of C4-C10 hydrocarbons is obtained at the bottom. The top stream consists of ethylene, propylene, and water, and thus, water is removed with a second flash unit prior to the purification and separation of ethylene-propylene. The water-free stream is, finally, fed into a second distillation column where polymer-grade ethylene and propylene are obtained at the top and bottom, respectively. The condenser of the second distillation unit operates at temperatures below ambient (ca. -21°C) and thus, a cooling cycle with a R134a working fluid was considered.;;;References:;Daniel F. Rodríguez-Vallejo, Gonzalo Guillén-Gosálbez, and Benoît Chachuat ACS Sustainable Chemistry & Engineering 2020 8 (8), 3072-3081 DOI: 10.1021/acssuschemeng.9b05516;Olah, G.A. (2005), Beyond Oil and Gas: The Methanol Economy. Angewandte Chemie International Edition, 44: 2636-2639. https://doi.org/10.1002/anie.200462121;Bertau, M., Offermanns, H., Plass, L., Schmidt, F., & Wernicke, H. J. (Eds.). (2014). Methanol: the basic chemical and energy feedstock of the future (Vol. 1). Heidelberg: Springer.
